trans-unit.source: Provides a durable reference to an object that is an instance of an entity type.
The <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> objects are immutable; that is, after they are constructed they cannot be modified.
For more information, see [Working with Entity Keys](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/fe3f4206-d277-43a1-a72f-4e86fdf12b9f).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> class.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> class with an entity set name and a generic <xref href="System.Collections.Generic.KeyValuePair"></xref> collection.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> that is the entity set name qualified by the entity container name.
A generic <xref href="System.Collections.Generic.KeyValuePair"></xref> collection.
Each key/value pair has a property name as the key and the value of that property as the value.
There should be one pair for each property that is part of the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref>.
The order of the key/value pairs is not important, but each key property should be included.
The property names are simple names that are not qualified with an entity type name or the schema name.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> class with an entity set name and an <xref href="System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1"></xref> collection of <xref href="System.Data.EntityKeyMember"></xref> objects.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> that is the entity set name qualified by the entity container name.
An <xref href="System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable`1"></xref> collection of <xref href="System.Data.EntityKeyMember"></xref> objects with which to initialize the key.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> class with an entity set name and specific entity key pair.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> that is the entity set name qualified by the entity container name.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> that is the name of the key.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> that is the key value.
Gets or sets the name of the entity container.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> value that is the name of the entity container for the entity to which the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> belongs.
Gets or sets the key values associated with this <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref>.
The <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> class contains a copy of the values that make up the logical key that is specified for this type of entity.

The members of the <xref:System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection%601> each have a property name and a value in a <xref:System.Collections.Generic.KeyValuePair%602>, where the key is the property name and the value is the actual value of that property on the object.
A <xref href="System.Collections.ObjectModel.ReadOnlyCollection`1"></xref> of key values for this <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref>.
A simple <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> identifying an entity that resulted from a failed [TREAT](~/docs/framework/data/adonet/ef/language-reference/treat-entity-sql.md) operation.
There are various ways to get an invalid entity.

The most common scenario is when an [!INCLUDE[esql](~/includes/esql-md.md)] query uses the [TREAT](~/docs/framework/data/adonet/ef/language-reference/treat-entity-sql.md) operator to interpret an instance of a polymorphic type as a particular type, and the instance in question does not match.
([TREAT](~/docs/framework/data/adonet/ef/language-reference/treat-entity-sql.md) is similar to the C# `as` operator).
In this case, the query returns an entity that is not valid, and the entity key of the resulting entity is set to <xref:System.Data.EntityKey.EntityNotValidKey>.
Gets or sets the name of the entity set.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> value that is the name of the entity set for the entity to which the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> belongs.
Returns a value that indicates whether this instance is equal to a specified object.
Temporary keys have different comparison semantics than permanent keys:
Temporary keys use reference equality.
That is, two references to the exact same temporary <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instance are equal but no other <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances are equal.
Permanent keys determine equality based on the values of the contained key properties and the <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet>.
That is, you can have two separate <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances that are equal if their <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet> objects are the same and their key values are equal.
In addition, temporary keys have no <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet> or key values, but permanent keys do.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> to compare with this instance.
`true` if this instance and obj have equal values; otherwise, `false`.
Returns a value that indicates whether this instance is equal to a specified <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref>.
Temporary keys have different comparison semantics than permanent keys:
Temporary keys use reference equality.
That is, two references to the exact same temporary <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instance are equal but no other <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances are equal.
Permanent keys determine equality based on the values of the contained key properties and the <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet>.
That is, you can have two separate <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances that are equal if their entity sets are the same and their key values are equal.
In addition, temporary keys have no <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet> or key values, but permanent keys do.
An <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> object to compare with this instance.
`true` if this instance and other have equal values; otherwise, `false`.
Gets the entity set for this entity key from the given metadata workspace.
The entity set is accessed based on the entity container name and entity set name of the key.
The metadata workspace that contains the entity.
The <xref href="System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet"></xref> for the entity key.
The entity set could not be located in the specified metadata workspace.
Serves as a hash function for the current <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> object.
<xref href="System.Data.EntityKey.GetHashCode"></xref> is suitable for hashing algorithms and data structures such as a hash table.
A hash code for the current <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref>.
Gets a value that indicates whether the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> is temporary.
When a new entity is created, the [!INCLUDE[adonet_ef](~/includes/adonet-ef-md.md)] defines temporary key and sets the <xref:System.Data.EntityKey.IsTemporary%2A> property to `true`.

When you call the <xref:System.Data.Objects.ObjectContext.SaveChanges%2A> method, the [!INCLUDE[adonet_ef](~/includes/adonet-ef-md.md)] assigns a permanent key and sets the <xref:System.Data.EntityKey.IsTemporary%2A> property to `false`.
Temporary keys are constructed automatically by the framework; they cannot be constructed directly by a user.
Temporary keys have different comparison semantics than permanent keys:
Temporary keys use reference equality.
That is, two references to the exact same temporary <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instance are equal but no other <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances are equal.
Permanent keys determine equality based on the values of the contained key properties and the <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet>.
That is, you can have two separate <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances that are equal if their entity sets are the same and their key values are equal.
In addition, temporary keys have no <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet> or key values, but permanent keys do.

When the <xref:System.Data.Objects.ObjectStateEntry.AcceptChanges%2A> method is called on an entity's <xref:System.Data.Objects.ObjectStateEntry> and the entity transitions from the <xref:System.Data.EntityState.Added> state to <xref:System.Data.EntityState.Unchanged> state, the [!INCLUDE[adonet_ef](~/includes/adonet-ef-md.md)] automatically computes a new permanent key for the entity and synchronizes all temporary key references.
`true` if the <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> is temporary; otherwise, `false`.
A singleton <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> by which a read-only entity is identified.
A read-only entity identifies an entity that is valid in every way, except that it is not associated with an actual entity set.

This can occur as part of the result of an [!INCLUDE[esql](~/includes/esql-md.md)] query that constructs and returns an entity instance specified within the text of the query (as opposed to an entity that was retrieved from a database table).
An entity that does not have an entity set cannot be persisted to the database until it is associated with some entity set.

Therefore, the object materializer will treat this kind of entity as if the <xref:System.Data.Objects.MergeOption.NoTracking> merge option was specified, regardless of the actual merge option that was specified.
An entity object will be created, but its identity will not be resolved and it will not be added to the state manager as part of the materialization process.
Helper method that is used to deserialize an <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref>.
<xref:System.Data.EntityKey.OnDeserialized%2A> is used by Object Services when deserializing an <xref:System.Data.EntityKey>.
For more information, see [Serializing Objects](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/06c77f9b-5b2e-4c78-b3e3-8c148ba0ea99).
Describes the source and destination of a given serialized stream and provides an additional caller-defined context.
Helper method that is used to deserialize an <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref>.
<xref:System.Data.EntityKey.OnDeserializing%2A> is used by Object Services when deserializing an <xref:System.Data.EntityKey>.
For more information, see [Serializing Objects](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/06c77f9b-5b2e-4c78-b3e3-8c148ba0ea99).
Describes the source and destination of a given serialized stream, and provides an additional caller-defined context.
Compares two <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> objects.
Temporary keys have different comparison semantics than permanent keys:
Temporary keys use reference equality.
That is, two references to the exact same temporary <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instance are equal but no other <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances are equal.
Permanent keys determine equality based on the values of the contained key properties and the <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet>.
That is, you can have two separate <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances that are equal if their entity sets are the same and their key values are equal.
In addition, temporary keys have no <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet> or key values, but permanent keys do.
The equivalent method for this operator is <xref:System.Data.EntityKey.Equals%28System.Data.EntityKey%2CSystem.Data.EntityKey%29?displayProperty=fullName>
A <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> to compare.
A <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> to compare.
`true` if the key1 and key2 values are equal; otherwise, `false`.
Compares two <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> objects.
Temporary keys have different comparison semantics than permanent keys:
Temporary keys use reference equality.
That is, two references to the exact same temporary <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instance are equal but no other <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances are equal.
Permanent keys determine equality based on the values of the contained key properties and the <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet>.
That is, you can have two separate <xref:System.Data.EntityKey> instances that are equal if their entity sets are the same and their key values are equal.
In addition, temporary keys have no <xref:System.Data.Metadata.Edm.EntitySet> or key values, but regular keys do.
The equivalent method for this operator is <xref:System.Data.EntityKey.Compare%28System.Data.EntityKey%2CSystem.Data.EntityKey%29?displayProperty=fullName>
A <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> to compare.
A <xref href="System.Data.EntityKey"></xref> to compare.
`true` if the key1 and key2 values are not equal; otherwise, `false`.
